elements.content: In situ ligand formation plays a unique role in the synthesis of metal–organic framework (MOF) materials. However, for a given metal–ligand system, in situ ligand formation can be limiting, especially for the synthesis of kinetically stable porous phases, because reaction conditions must be chosen to meet the requirements of both in situ ligand formation and MOF crystal growth. Such requirements may be mutually incompatible, because ligand formation involving the breaking of inert bonds may require conditions more harsh than those needed for the growth of porous materials. For homochiral MOFs, less harsh reaction conditions are also desirable because of the reduced risk for ligand racemization. In this study, we propose and demonstrate the concept that the use of presynthesized ligand (in place of in situ-formed ligand) to decouple the ligand synthesis reaction from MOF crystal growth allows access to more porous and kinetically stable phases that may not be possible through the in situ process. A homochiral Zn-d-camphorate-TPB system (TPB = 1,2,4,5-tetra­(4-pyridyl)­benzene) is chosen to illustrate this concept. A new homochiral MOF (CPM-322) has been synthesized that contains infinite homochiral sheets of zinc paddlewheel dimers and d-camphorate ligands. An exceptional feature is the novel X-pillaring mechanism, in distinct contrast with simple pillaring by rod-like ditopic ligands (here called the I-pillaring mechanism). The perfect geometry matching in both pillaring distances and angles between TPB X-pillars and wavy homochiral sheets allows the TPB ligand to act as X-shaped pillars that prop up homochiral layers with two pyridyl groups on each side, leading to a highly open and rigid three-dimensional homochiral porous framework.
elements.clean_text: In situ ligand formation plays a unique role in the synthesis of metal-organic framework (MOF) materials. However, for a given metal-ligand system, in situ ligand formation can be limiting, especially for the synthesis of kinetically stable porous phases, because reaction conditions must be chosen to meet the requirements of both in situ ligand formation and MOF crystal growth. Such requirements may be mutually incompatible, because ligand formation involving the breaking of inert bonds may require conditions more harsh than those needed for the growth of porous materials. For homochiral MOFs, less harsh reaction conditions are also desirable because of the reduced risk for ligand racemization. In this study, we propose and demonstrate the concept that the use of presynthesized ligand (in place of in situ-formed ligand) to decouple the ligand synthesis reaction from MOF crystal growth allows access to more porous and kinetically stable phases that may not be possible through the in situ process. A homochiral Zn-d-camphorate-TPB system (TPB = 1,2,4,5-tetra(4-pyridyl)benzene) is chosen to illustrate this concept. A new homochiral MOF (CPM-322) has been synthesized that contains infinite homochiral sheets of zinc paddlewheel dimers and d-camphorate ligands. An exceptional feature is the novel X-pillaring mechanism, in distinct contrast with simple pillaring by rod-like ditopic ligands (here called the I-pillaring mechanism). The perfect geometry matching in both pillaring distances and angles between TPB X-pillars and wavy homochiral sheets allows the TPB ligand to act as X-shaped pillars that prop up homochiral layers with two pyridyl groups on each side, leading to a highly open and rigid three-dimensional homochiral porous framework.

elements.content: A homochiral metal−organic framework was synthesized that contains sheets of paddlewheel zinc dimers and d-camphorate. An exceptional feature is the X-pillaring mechanism. The perfect geometry matching between TPB ligands (TPB = 1,2,4,5-tetra­(4-pyridyl)­benzene) and wavy sheets allows TPB to act as X-shaped pillars, propping up homochiral layers with all four pyridyl groups, leading to an open and rigid three-dimensional homochiral framework.
elements.clean_text: A homochiral metal-organic framework was synthesized that contains sheets of paddlewheel zinc dimers and d-camphorate. An exceptional feature is the X-pillaring mechanism. The perfect geometry matching between TPB ligands (TPB = 1,2,4,5-tetra(4-pyridyl)benzene) and wavy sheets allows TPB to act as X-shaped pillars, propping up homochiral layers with all four pyridyl groups, leading to an open and rigid three-dimensional homochiral framework.

elements.content: Crystalline porous materials (CPMs) have attracted wide research interest because their porous property can be useful for many applications including catalysis, separation and storage of gas molecules, and ion exchange. Among various types of CPMs, homochiral crystalline porous materials have potential applications in a range of size- and enantioselective catalysis and separations because they integrate uniform pore size, high surface area, and homochirality. However, while the generation of chirality in either molecules or crystals is not uncommon, the resulting bulk samples tend to be disappointedly racemic. The generation of bulk homochirality, particularly in porous materials, is synthetically challenging. This is especially true for inorganic porous materials such as zeolites in which the framework is made exclusively from inorganic building blocks that can rarely be obtained in enantiopure forms.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Crystalline porous materials (CPMs) have attracted wide research interest because their porous property can be useful for many applications including catalysis, separation and storage of gas molecules, and ion exchange. Among various types of CPMs, homochiral crystalline porous materials have potential applications in a range of size- and enantioselective catalysis and separations because they integrate uniform pore size, high surface area, and homochirality. However, while the generation of chirality in either molecules or crystals is not uncommon, the resulting bulk samples tend to be disappointedly racemic. The generation of bulk homochirality, particularly in porous materials, is synthetically challenging. This is especially true for inorganic porous materials such as zeolites in which the framework is made exclusively from inorganic building blocks that can rarely be obtained in enantiopure forms.

elements.content: Compared to inorganic porous materials, metal–organic framework (MOF) materials offer new opportunities for designing homochiral porous materials, primarily because it is much easier to find enantiopure organic building blocks, some of which even exist naturally. While enantiopure organic molecules can be included in different ways, for example, as structure-directing agents detached from the framework (zero-point of attachment to the framework) or as a pendant grafted to the surface of the framework (one-point or one-side of attachment to the framework), the most common method for homochirality generation in MOFs is still the use of di- or polyfunctional enantiopure ligands to serve as the cross-linker to form porous MOFs. However, this method is restricted by a limited number of enantiopure cross-linking ligands, some of which are also costly. One way that can significantly expand the diversity of homochiral materials is to construct them by the combined use of an enantiopure ligand with one or more types of achiral auxiliary ligands. Since there are many choices of achiral ligands, many more homochiral CPMs can be made this way. Furthermore, the chiral environment may be tunable by the ratio between chiral and achiral ligands.
elements.clean_text: Compared to inorganic porous materials, metal-organic framework (MOF) materials offer new opportunities for designing homochiral porous materials, primarily because it is much easier to find enantiopure organic building blocks, some of which even exist naturally. While enantiopure organic molecules can be included in different ways, for example, as structure-directing agents detached from the framework (zero-point of attachment to the framework) or as a pendant grafted to the surface of the framework (one-point or one-side of attachment to the framework), the most common method for homochirality generation in MOFs is still the use of di- or polyfunctional enantiopure ligands to serve as the cross-linker to form porous MOFs. However, this method is restricted by a limited number of enantiopure cross-linking ligands, some of which are also costly. One way that can significantly expand the diversity of homochiral materials is to construct them by the combined use of an enantiopure ligand with one or more types of achiral auxiliary ligands. Since there are many choices of achiral ligands, many more homochiral CPMs can be made this way. Furthermore, the chiral environment may be tunable by the ratio between chiral and achiral ligands.

elements.content: A large number of ligands have been used either alone or in combination with others (i.e., the mixed ligand approach) in the synthesis of MOFs. Of particular interest is a small subset of these ligands formed in situ during solvothermal growth of MOF crystals. In these cases, the ligand synthesis and MOF formation are coupled together either sequentially or concurrently in a one-pot synthesis. Some in situ ligand formation reactions involve the breaking of inert bonds (e.g., C–H bond) and are less likely to occur under conditions (e.g, temperature, pressure, solvents) used for the MOF synthesis if it were not due to the assistance through the formation of MOF crystals. Factors that may promote the in situ ligand formation can be quite complicated and may include the templating effect of metal ions and shifting of chemical equilibrium due to crystallization. For structures involving both in situ formed ligand and another axillary ligand (La), the metal-La substructure may also help induce the in situ ligand formation. Finally, additives can play an essential and perhaps catalytic role in the in situ ligand formation.
elements.clean_text: A large number of ligands have been used either alone or in combination with others (i.e., the mixed ligand approach) in the synthesis of MOFs. Of particular interest is a small subset of these ligands formed in situ during solvothermal growth of MOF crystals. In these cases, the ligand synthesis and MOF formation are coupled together either sequentially or concurrently in a one-pot synthesis. Some in situ ligand formation reactions involve the breaking of inert bonds (e.g., C-H bond) and are less likely to occur under conditions (e.g, temperature, pressure, solvents) used for the MOF synthesis if it were not due to the assistance through the formation of MOF crystals. Factors that may promote the in situ ligand formation can be quite complicated and may include the templating effect of metal ions and shifting of chemical equilibrium due to crystallization. For structures involving both in situ formed ligand and another axillary ligand (La), the metal-La substructure may also help induce the in situ ligand formation. Finally, additives can play an essential and perhaps catalytic role in the in situ ligand formation.

elements.content: One approach that may offer a route for new MOF materials and at the same time provide some insight into the MOF formation from in situ-formed ligands is to perform a comparative study: one involving in situ ligand formation (here called the coupled MOF synthesis) and one starting from the presynthesized ligand (here called the decoupled MOF synthesis). So far, even though many MOF syntheses involving in situ ligand formation have been reported, there have been few such comparative studies. From the perspective of developing new MOF materials, decoupling the ligand synthesis from the MOF synthesis can be more advantageous than the coupled synthesis involving the in situ ligand synthesis. This is because the reaction conditions for the coupled synthesis have to be chosen to favor both ligand formation and MOF crystal growth simultaneously. For ligand formation involving the breaking of inert bonds, reaction conditions can be significantly more harsh (e.g., higher temperature) that those typically used for MOF crystal growth. In comparison, for the decoupled synthesis that makes use of presynthesized ligands, reactions conditions only need to be optimized for the MOF crystal growth and can be milder and more varied. It is worth noting that mild reaction conditions tend to favor MOFs with higher porosity, and for the synthesis of homochiral porous materials, mild conditions are also beneficial because they help reduce the probability of ligand racemization.
elements.clean_text: One approach that may offer a route for new MOF materials and at the same time provide some insight into the MOF formation from in situ-formed ligands is to perform a comparative study: one involving in situ ligand formation (here called the coupled MOF synthesis) and one starting from the presynthesized ligand (here called the decoupled MOF synthesis). So far, even though many MOF syntheses involving in situ ligand formation have been reported, there have been few such comparative studies. From the perspective of developing new MOF materials, decoupling the ligand synthesis from the MOF synthesis can be more advantageous than the coupled synthesis involving the in situ ligand synthesis. This is because the reaction conditions for the coupled synthesis have to be chosen to favor both ligand formation and MOF crystal growth simultaneously. For ligand formation involving the breaking of inert bonds, reaction conditions can be significantly more harsh (e.g., higher temperature) that those typically used for MOF crystal growth. In comparison, for the decoupled synthesis that makes use of presynthesized ligands, reactions conditions only need to be optimized for the MOF crystal growth and can be milder and more varied. It is worth noting that mild reaction conditions tend to favor MOFs with higher porosity, and for the synthesis of homochiral porous materials, mild conditions are also beneficial because they help reduce the probability of ligand racemization.

elements.content: Prior to this study, we reported the synthesis of a homochiral MOF, Zn­(d-cam)­(TMDPy)­(H2O) (TMDPy = 4,4′-trimethylenedipyridine), by combining a chiral ligand with an achiral ligand. In a follow-up study, we found that the addition of additives such as GeO2 (or H3BO3) results in a dehydrogenative in situ reaction between two TMDPy molecules to form the TPB ligand (TPB = 1,2,4,5-tetra­(4-pyridyl)­benzene), which gives rise to the synthesis of another homochiral MOF, [Zn­(d-cam)]­(TPB)1/2]­(H2O)1/2 (denoted CPM-321, ). Given our interest in developing new homochiral MOFs, we were curious about whether CPM-321 is thermodynamically the most favored product for the assembly between Zn2+, d-cam, and TPB. To address this issue and to search for new homochiral MOFs, we decided to abandon the reliance on in situ formation of TPB and instead chose to employ the presynthesized TPB. This approach allows us to examine the effect of the auxiliary ligand on the resulting MOF structure by comparing reactions involving in situ-formed TPB and presynthesized TPB. We report here a novel homochiral MOF, [Zn2(d-cam)2]­(TPB)1/2] (denoted CPM-322), prepared from presynthesized TPB. It has an unusual X-pillar-layered structure, in which homochiral layers formed by Zn2(COO)4 paddlewheel dimers and d-cam ligands are pillared by X-shaped TPB ligand, in distinct contrast with other pillar-layered structures that are usually made from rod-like ditopic ligands.
elements.clean_text: Prior to this study, we reported the synthesis of a homochiral MOF, Zn(d-cam)(TMDPy)(H2O) (TMDPy = 4,4'-trimethylenedipyridine), by combining a chiral ligand with an achiral ligand. In a follow-up study, we found that the addition of additives such as GeO2 (or H3BO3) results in a dehydrogenative in situ reaction between two TMDPy molecules to form the TPB ligand (TPB = 1,2,4,5-tetra(4-pyridyl)benzene), which gives rise to the synthesis of another homochiral MOF, [Zn(d-cam)](TPB)1/2](H2O)1/2 (denoted CPM-321, ). Given our interest in developing new homochiral MOFs, we were curious about whether CPM-321 is thermodynamically the most favored product for the assembly between Zn2+, d-cam, and TPB. To address this issue and to search for new homochiral MOFs, we decided to abandon the reliance on in situ formation of TPB and instead chose to employ the presynthesized TPB. This approach allows us to examine the effect of the auxiliary ligand on the resulting MOF structure by comparing reactions involving in situ-formed TPB and presynthesized TPB. We report here a novel homochiral MOF, [Zn2(d-cam)2](TPB)1/2] (denoted CPM-322), prepared from presynthesized TPB. It has an unusual X-pillar-layered structure, in which homochiral layers formed by Zn2(COO)4 paddlewheel dimers and d-cam ligands are pillared by X-shaped TPB ligand, in distinct contrast with other pillar-layered structures that are usually made from rod-like ditopic ligands.

Schematic Illustration on the Synthesis of Two Homochiral Frameworks through Two Different Routes<xref rid="sch1-fn1"></xref>

With in situ synthesized TPB ligand, CPM-321 was obtained (top) and through pre-synthesized ligand, CPM-322 was obtained (bottom).
elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic Illustration on the Synthesis of Two Homochiral Frameworks through Two Different Routes      a With in situ synthesized TPB ligand, CPM-321 was obtained (top) and through pre-synthesized ligand, CPM-322 was obtained (bottom).

elements.content:
With in situ synthesized TPB ligand, CPM-321 was obtained (top) and through pre-synthesized ligand, CPM-322 was obtained (bottom).

Experimental SectionSynthesis of CPM-322 (Zn<sub>2</sub>(<sc>d</sc>-cam)<sub>2</sub>(TPB)<sub>0.5</sub>)

In a 23 mL glass vial, 11.0 mg of d-H2Cam, 11.0 mg of TPB (synthesized according to the literature method), and 34.8 mg of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O were dissolved in 5.0 g of DMF. After being stirred for 30 min, the vial was placed in a 120 °C oven for 4 days, and the mixture was then cooled to room temperature. Pure colorless crystals were obtained (78.0% yield based on metal). The phase purity was supported by powder X-ray diffraction (Figure S1).
elements.clean_text:
a With in situ synthesized TPB ligand, CPM-321 was obtained (top) and through pre-synthesized ligand, CPM-322 was obtained (bottom).  

Experimental Section

Synthesis of CPM-322 (Zn2(d-cam)2(TPB)0.5)

In a 23 mL glass vial, 11.0 mg of d-H2Cam, 11.0 mg of TPB (synthesized according to the literature method), and 34.8 mg of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O were dissolved in 5.0 g of DMF. After being stirred for 30 min, the vial was placed in a 120 °C oven for 4 days, and the mixture was then cooled to room temperature. Pure colorless crystals were obtained (78.0% yield based on metal). The phase purity was supported by powder X-ray diffraction (Figure S1).

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray analysis was performed on a Bruker Smart APEX II CCD area diffractometer with nitrogen-flow temperature controller using graphite-monochromated MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å), operating in the ω and φ scan mode. The SADABS program was used for absorption correction. The structure was solved by direct methods followed by successive difference Fourier methods. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Computations were performed using SHELXTL, and final full-matrix refinements were against F 2.
elements.clean_text:
Single Crystal X-ray Crystallography Studies

Single crystal X-ray analysis was performed on a Bruker Smart APEX II CCD area diffractometer with nitrogen-flow temperature controller using graphite-monochromated MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å), operating in the ω and φ scan mode. The SADABS program was used for absorption correction. The structure was solved by direct methods followed by successive difference Fourier methods. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Computations were performed using SHELXTL, and final full-matrix refinements were against F 2.

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction experiments were performed on a PANalytical X’Pert Pro MPD diffractometer, equipped with a linear X’Celerator detector, which was operating at 40 kV and 35 mA (CuKα radiation, λ = 1.5418 Å). The data collection was performed at room temperature from 8° to 40° with a step size of ∼0.008°.
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction

Powder X-ray diffraction experiments were performed on a PANalytical X'Pert Pro MPD diffractometer, equipped with a linear X'Celerator detector, which was operating at 40 kV and 35 mA (CuKα radiation, λ = 1.5418 Å). The data collection was performed at room temperature from 8° to 40° with a step size of ~0.008°.

elements.content: The simultaneous DSC-TGA was performed on TA Instruments SDT Q600 in the temperature range of 30–900 °C under the flowing nitrogen atmosphere. The flow rate of the nitrogen gas was controlled at about 60 mL per minute. The heating rate was 10 °C/min.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analysis

The simultaneous DSC-TGA was performed on TA Instruments SDT Q600 in the temperature range of 30-900 °C under the flowing nitrogen atmosphere. The flow rate of the nitrogen gas was controlled at about 60 mL per minute. The heating rate was 10 °C/min.

elements.content: Gas sorption experiments were carried out on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 Plus surface area and pore size analyzer. The as-synthesized sample was purified by three cycles of sonicating and removal of upper solutions. The purified crystalline sample was immersed in dichloromethane for 3 days, during which the dichloromethane was refreshed twice a day. The treated sample was filtered and further evacuated under 80 °C for 10 h.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Sorption Measurements

Gas sorption experiments were carried out on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 Plus surface area and pore size analyzer. The as-synthesized sample was purified by three cycles of sonicating and removal of upper solutions. The purified crystalline sample was immersed in dichloromethane for 3 days, during which the dichloromethane was refreshed twice a day. The treated sample was filtered and further evacuated under 80 °C for 10 h.

elements.content: In this work, by reacting zinc nitrate, d-camphoric acid, and the presynthesized TPB ligand in DMF at 120 °C, a new compound named CPM-322 was obtained. This compound can also be obtained in a mixed solvent of 1,3-dimethylpropyleneurea (DMPU) and water at an even lower temperature (100 °C) (Table S1). However, no crystallization of CPM-322 was observed when reaction temperatures corresponding to the synthesis of CPM-321 (i.e., 165 °C) were used. These results, together with the results from other variations of synthesis conditions (Table S1), demonstrate that CPM-322 is a low-temperature phase, accessible only through the decoupled synthesis, while CPM-321 is a high-temperature phase, accessible through the coupled synthesis involving in situ ligand synthesis. The structure of CPM-322, Zn2(d-cam)2(TPB)0.5, was determined by single crystal X-ray crystallography (). With the incorporation of an enantiopure d-camphorate ligand, it crystallizes in a chiral orthorhombic space group I222, higher in symmetry than CPM-321 (space group P21).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

In this work, by reacting zinc nitrate, d-camphoric acid, and the presynthesized TPB ligand in DMF at 120 °C, a new compound named CPM-322 was obtained. This compound can also be obtained in a mixed solvent of 1,3-dimethylpropyleneurea (DMPU) and water at an even lower temperature (100 °C) (Table S1). However, no crystallization of CPM-322 was observed when reaction temperatures corresponding to the synthesis of CPM-321 (i.e., 165 °C) were used. These results, together with the results from other variations of synthesis conditions (Table S1), demonstrate that CPM-322 is a low-temperature phase, accessible only through the decoupled synthesis, while CPM-321 is a high-temperature phase, accessible through the coupled synthesis involving in situ ligand synthesis. The structure of CPM-322, Zn2(d-cam)2(TPB)0.5, was determined by single crystal X-ray crystallography (). With the incorporation of an enantiopure d-camphorate ligand, it crystallizes in a chiral orthorhombic space group I222, higher in symmetry than CPM-321 (space group P21).

Crystal and Refinement Data for CPM-322 CPM-322 empirical formula Zn2C33H37N2O8 formula weight 720.38 temperature (K) 174(2) crystal system, space group orthorhombic space group I222 unit cell dimensions a = 18.4486(11) Å, b = 19.2044(12) Å, c = 31.3758(18) Å, V = 11116.3(12) Å3 Z 8 density 0.861 g/cm3 absorption coefficient 0.894 mm–1 F(000) 2984 reflections collected/unique 35437/9739 [R(int) = 0.0604] data completeness measured (%) 99.5 parameter/restraints/data (obs) 406/30/7055 goodness-of-fit 0.984 final R indices (I > 2σ(I)) R 1 = 0.0556, wR 2 = 0.1371 R indices (all) R 1 = 0.0735, wR 2 = 0.1440 Flack’s parameter 0.018(11) largest difference peaks 1.05 and −0.40 e·A–3

R 1 = ∑(|F 0| – |F c|)/∑|F 0|, wR 2 = [∑w­(F 0 2 – F c 2)2/∑w(F o 2+)2]0.5.

One very interesting structural feature is the presence of a quite regular [Zn2(COO)4] paddlewheel unit (). Even though the [Zn2(COO)4] paddlewheel unit is common in MOFs, it is far less common in homochiral MOFs with low-symmetry enantiopure ligands. In fact, to our knowledge, the [M2(COO)4] paddlewheel of any metal ion had never been found in d-camphorate based homochiral MOFs prior to this work. It is worth noting that there are many highly porous and desirable framework topologies (formed from achiral and relatively high-symmetry ligands) that have not been shown to be accessible by chiral ligands. Understanding similarities and differences between chiral and achiral ligands in accessing various building units and framework topologies would be interesting in the development of homochiral porous materials. In this work, being able to access paddlewheel units with d-camphorate highlights an important similarity between d-camphorate and high-symmetry ligands.
elements.clean_text: One very interesting structural feature is the presence of a quite regular [Zn2(COO)4] paddlewheel unit (). Even though the [Zn2(COO)4] paddlewheel unit is common in MOFs, it is far less common in homochiral MOFs with low-symmetry enantiopure ligands. In fact, to our knowledge, the [M2(COO)4] paddlewheel of any metal ion had never been found in d-camphorate based homochiral MOFs prior to this work. It is worth noting that there are many highly porous and desirable framework topologies (formed from achiral and relatively high-symmetry ligands) that have not been shown to be accessible by chiral ligands. Understanding similarities and differences between chiral and achiral ligands in accessing various building units and framework topologies would be interesting in the development of homochiral porous materials. In this work, being able to access paddlewheel units with d-camphorate highlights an important similarity between d-camphorate and high-symmetry ligands.

elements.content: Local structural feature in CPM-322. (a) The occurrence of size and symmetry matching between TPB ligand and two adjacent paddlewheel units makes it possible for multiple connection between the pillar and layer. (b) A comparison between the distorted paddlewheel in CPM-322 (top) and a regular paddlewheel (bottom).
elements.clean_text: 1  Local structural feature in CPM-322. (a) The occurrence of size and symmetry matching between TPB ligand and two adjacent paddlewheel units makes it possible for multiple connection between the pillar and layer. (b) A comparison between the distorted paddlewheel in CPM-322 (top) and a regular paddlewheel (bottom).

elements.content: Another interesting feature is the observation that TPB serves as the X-shaped pillar for the wavy 4,4-square net formed from the cross-linking of [M2(COO)4] paddlewheel unit by d-camphorate (). In common pillar-layered structures, the pillar is usually a ditopic ligand such as those similar to 4,4-bipyridine (i.e., the I-pillaring mechanism). CPM-322, however, is different, and its four pyridyl groups of the tetratopic ligand all participate in pillaring. This is an exceptionally unusual feature. This is because in order for an X-shaped ligand to use all four coordination sites for the pillaring purpose, the separation between metal coordination sites (approximately 9.15 Å) within the sheet (in this case, two axial bonding sites of two adjacent paddlewheel units) as well as the angle between two paddlewheel rods (both of which are determined by the size and bent angles between two −COO groups in camphorate) has to match precisely with the separation of two donor atoms and their bite angle (67.2° in TPB, ) in the X-shaped ligand (in this case, two N sites of two pyridyl groups at 1 and 2 positions as well as those at 4 and 5 positions) (). Such stringent geometric requirements in both distance and angles for both metal sites and ligands is generally unnecessary for structures pillared with a ditopic ligand.
elements.clean_text: Another interesting feature is the observation that TPB serves as the X-shaped pillar for the wavy 4,4-square net formed from the cross-linking of [M2(COO)4] paddlewheel unit by d-camphorate (). In common pillar-layered structures, the pillar is usually a ditopic ligand such as those similar to 4,4-bipyridine (i.e., the I-pillaring mechanism). CPM-322, however, is different, and its four pyridyl groups of the tetratopic ligand all participate in pillaring. This is an exceptionally unusual feature. This is because in order for an X-shaped ligand to use all four coordination sites for the pillaring purpose, the separation between metal coordination sites (approximately 9.15 Å) within the sheet (in this case, two axial bonding sites of two adjacent paddlewheel units) as well as the angle between two paddlewheel rods (both of which are determined by the size and bent angles between two -COO groups in camphorate) has to match precisely with the separation of two donor atoms and their bite angle (67.2° in TPB, ) in the X-shaped ligand (in this case, two N sites of two pyridyl groups at 1 and 2 positions as well as those at 4 and 5 positions) (). Such stringent geometric requirements in both distance and angles for both metal sites and ligands is generally unnecessary for structures pillared with a ditopic ligand.

elements.content: Structure illustration of CPM-322 (a) the square net constructed by Zn paddlewheel and d-camphorate, (b) the sql layers are further pillared by tetradentate TPB ligand to form a 3D framework, and (c) the simplified net showing the connectivity. Cyan balls represent the Zn dimer and gold balls represent the center of TPB.
elements.clean_text: 2  Structure illustration of CPM-322 (a) the square net constructed by Zn paddlewheel and d-camphorate, (b) the sql layers are further pillared by tetradentate TPB ligand to form a 3D framework, and (c) the simplified net showing the connectivity. Cyan balls represent the Zn dimer and gold balls represent the center of TPB.

elements.content: TPB and camphorate are a surprising pair of matching ligands, because it is the perfect and multifaceted geometry matching between TPB ligand and the wavy 2D layer (resulting from the nonlinear d-camphorate) that is responsible for the match between the separation of two pyridyl N-donor sites and the separation of two adjacent Zn dimers () and between the orientation of two dimers and the orientation of two pyridyl groups. If the camphorate ligand were replaced by a linear ditopic ligand such as terephthalate, a planar square net would have been formed (as compared to the wavy square net formed by camphorate), in which case, the paddlewheels would have been arranged in parallel (0° instead of about 67° in CPM-322) and would not have been in the suitable orientation to bond to two pyridyl groups on TPB (even if the separation is at the correct distance). It is expected that this X-shaped pillaring scheme could offer greater structural rigidity compared to the pillaring by a ditoptic ligand in which the ditopic ligand can adopt a range of tilt angle with respect to layers being pillared.
elements.clean_text: TPB and camphorate are a surprising pair of matching ligands, because it is the perfect and multifaceted geometry matching between TPB ligand and the wavy 2D layer (resulting from the nonlinear d-camphorate) that is responsible for the match between the separation of two pyridyl N-donor sites and the separation of two adjacent Zn dimers () and between the orientation of two dimers and the orientation of two pyridyl groups. If the camphorate ligand were replaced by a linear ditopic ligand such as terephthalate, a planar square net would have been formed (as compared to the wavy square net formed by camphorate), in which case, the paddlewheels would have been arranged in parallel (0° instead of about 67° in CPM-322) and would not have been in the suitable orientation to bond to two pyridyl groups on TPB (even if the separation is at the correct distance). It is expected that this X-shaped pillaring scheme could offer greater structural rigidity compared to the pillaring by a ditoptic ligand in which the ditopic ligand can adopt a range of tilt angle with respect to layers being pillared.

elements.content: In a homochiral MOF constructed from the integration of chiral and achiral ligands, the ratio between chiral and achiral ligands affects the dimensionality of metal–ligand connectivity and the overall chiral environment of the porous framework. In CPM-322, the 3D homochiral framework is based on 2D homochiral connectivity (i.e., Zn2-d-camphorate infinite sheets) and 1D achiral connectivity through TPB X-pillars. Using the earlier proposed classification scheme for homochiral MOFs, CPM-322 can be classified as the C2A1 type structure (C = chiral connectivity; A = achiral connectivity).
elements.clean_text: In a homochiral MOF constructed from the integration of chiral and achiral ligands, the ratio between chiral and achiral ligands affects the dimensionality of metal-ligand connectivity and the overall chiral environment of the porous framework. In CPM-322, the 3D homochiral framework is based on 2D homochiral connectivity (i.e., Zn2-d-camphorate infinite sheets) and 1D achiral connectivity through TPB X-pillars. Using the earlier proposed classification scheme for homochiral MOFs, CPM-322 can be classified as the C2A1 type structure (C = chiral connectivity; A = achiral connectivity).

elements.content: CPM-322, [Zn2(d-cam)2]­(TPB)1/2], synthesized from the presynthesized TPB ligand, is distinctly different from [Zn­(d-cam)­(TPB)1/2]­(H2O)1/2 (denoted CPM-321) synthesized from the in situ-formed TPB through coupling reaction between two TMDPy molecules. First, the inorganic node and the metal coordination environments are dramatically different. In CPM-321, the metal node is a tetrahedrally coordinated monomeric Zn2+ bonded to two pyridyl groups and two carboxylate groups. In contrast, in CPM-322, the inorganic node is a six-connected paddlewheel dimer, bonded to four carboxylate groups and two pyridyl groups.
elements.clean_text: CPM-322, [Zn2(d-cam)2](TPB)1/2], synthesized from the presynthesized TPB ligand, is distinctly different from [Zn(d-cam)(TPB)1/2](H2O)1/2 (denoted CPM-321) synthesized from the in situ-formed TPB through coupling reaction between two TMDPy molecules. First, the inorganic node and the metal coordination environments are dramatically different. In CPM-321, the metal node is a tetrahedrally coordinated monomeric Zn2+ bonded to two pyridyl groups and two carboxylate groups. In contrast, in CPM-322, the inorganic node is a six-connected paddlewheel dimer, bonded to four carboxylate groups and two pyridyl groups.

elements.content: Another notable difference between CPM-322 and CPM-321 is in the ratio between chiral and achiral ligands. CPM-322 with a d-cam/TPB ratio of 4 exhibits a richer homochiral environment than CPM-321 with a d-cam/TPB ratio of 2. Such a difference in the ratio between chiral and achiral ligands is directly related to the difference in metal–ligand connectivity. To better explain the structural difference between CPM-322 and CPM-321, it is helpful to distinguish two different roles of ligands in pillar-layered structures: layer-forming vs pillaring. In CPM-321, the layer consists of a 4-connected layer-forming TPB ligand and a Zn2+ monomer, which is subsequently pillared by ditopic d-camphorate ligand through two remaining coordination sites on each Zn2+ (using the I-pillaring mechanism). In CPM-322, the roles of TPB and camphorate are switched. The layer consists of 4-connected Zn2 paddlewheels and 2-connected layer-forming d-camphorate, which is subsequently pillared by X-shaped tetratopic TPB ligands (Figure S2).
elements.clean_text: Another notable difference between CPM-322 and CPM-321 is in the ratio between chiral and achiral ligands. CPM-322 with a d-cam/TPB ratio of 4 exhibits a richer homochiral environment than CPM-321 with a d-cam/TPB ratio of 2. Such a difference in the ratio between chiral and achiral ligands is directly related to the difference in metal-ligand connectivity. To better explain the structural difference between CPM-322 and CPM-321, it is helpful to distinguish two different roles of ligands in pillar-layered structures: layer-forming vs pillaring. In CPM-321, the layer consists of a 4-connected layer-forming TPB ligand and a Zn2+ monomer, which is subsequently pillared by ditopic d-camphorate ligand through two remaining coordination sites on each Zn2+ (using the I-pillaring mechanism). In CPM-322, the roles of TPB and camphorate are switched. The layer consists of 4-connected Zn2 paddlewheels and 2-connected layer-forming d-camphorate, which is subsequently pillared by X-shaped tetratopic TPB ligands (Figure S2).

elements.content: A more detailed structural analysis shows that CPM-322 is quite porous, and there is a grid-shaped channel system within the framework. When viewed along the b axis, there is a hexagonal shaped channel through the framework (). This large channel may be potentially useful for inclusion of guest molecules for applications such as gas sorption or chiral separation. A narrower channel can be seen along the a axis (). A calculation by the Platon routine shows that CPM-322 has 51.5% void space, much higher than the void space in CPM-321 (only ∼7.7%).
elements.clean_text: A more detailed structural analysis shows that CPM-322 is quite porous, and there is a grid-shaped channel system within the framework. When viewed along the b axis, there is a hexagonal shaped channel through the framework (). This large channel may be potentially useful for inclusion of guest molecules for applications such as gas sorption or chiral separation. A narrower channel can be seen along the a axis (). A calculation by the Platon routine shows that CPM-322 has 51.5% void space, much higher than the void space in CPM-321 (only ~7.7%).

elements.content: A perspective view along the b axis showing the hexagonal-shaped channel in CPM-322.
elements.clean_text: 3  A perspective view along the b axis showing the hexagonal-shaped channel in CPM-322.

elements.content: Such a difference in porosity between CPM-322 and CPM-321 highlights the rationale and success of our synthetic strategies of exploring the use of presynthesized ligands in comparison with in situ formed ligands in order to access metastable phase domains. CPM-321, being less porous and likely more thermodynamically stable than CPM-322, is synthesized at a higher temperature which is also simultaneously needed for the in situ formation of TPB ligand. By decoupling the in situ ligand reaction from the crystal growth, we are able to use lower reaction temperatures which make it possible to access metastable phases, and a result, CPM-322, with a porosity significantly greater than CPM-321, was synthesized.
elements.clean_text: Such a difference in porosity between CPM-322 and CPM-321 highlights the rationale and success of our synthetic strategies of exploring the use of presynthesized ligands in comparison with in situ formed ligands in order to access metastable phase domains. CPM-321, being less porous and likely more thermodynamically stable than CPM-322, is synthesized at a higher temperature which is also simultaneously needed for the in situ formation of TPB ligand. By decoupling the in situ ligand reaction from the crystal growth, we are able to use lower reaction temperatures which make it possible to access metastable phases, and a result, CPM-322, with a porosity significantly greater than CPM-321, was synthesized.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis on the as-synthesized sample shows that an initial weight loss of about 25% occurs below 120 °C, which is mainly due to the removal of solvent and other guest molecules (Figure S5). The plateau lasts to about 350 °C with minor weight loss. After that, an obvious weight loss was observed, likely due to the collapse of the structure. In comparison, the weight loss of CPM-321 starts at a lower temperature around 300 °C. The pore properties of CPM-322 were evaluated after successful degassing of the sample (Figure S6). Different methods were used to activate the sample including direct heating and solvent exchange with methanol or dichloromethane. The best result was obtained after solvent exchange with dichloromethane for 3 days followed by further degas at 80 °C. For CPM-322, the CO2 uptake at 1 bar and 273 K reaches 48.8 mg/g.
elements.clean_text: Thermogravimetric analysis on the as-synthesized sample shows that an initial weight loss of about 25% occurs below 120 °C, which is mainly due to the removal of solvent and other guest molecules (Figure S5). The plateau lasts to about 350 °C with minor weight loss. After that, an obvious weight loss was observed, likely due to the collapse of the structure. In comparison, the weight loss of CPM-321 starts at a lower temperature around 300 °C. The pore properties of CPM-322 were evaluated after successful degassing of the sample (Figure S6). Different methods were used to activate the sample including direct heating and solvent exchange with methanol or dichloromethane. The best result was obtained after solvent exchange with dichloromethane for 3 days followed by further degas at 80 °C. For CPM-322, the CO2 uptake at 1 bar and 273 K reaches 48.8 mg/g.

elements.content: In conclusion, by using the presynthesized TPB ligand, a new type of pillar-layered homochiral material CPM-322 with X-shaped pillars and zinc paddle wheels was successfully obtained, which cannot be obtained through the in situ ligand formation method. Compared to CPM-321, formed through the in situ method, CPM-322 is more porous due to our strategy that the decoupled synthesis permits the use of milder reaction conditions. More importantly, intentional decoupling of the ligand formation process from the MOF crystal growth process provides a new and more flexible route in the kinetic control of MOF synthesis, which may be applied as a general strategy for creating new MOFs, especially homochiral MOFs involving enantiopure ligands (e.g., amino acids) that have the risk of racemization.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, by using the presynthesized TPB ligand, a new type of pillar-layered homochiral material CPM-322 with X-shaped pillars and zinc paddle wheels was successfully obtained, which cannot be obtained through the in situ ligand formation method. Compared to CPM-321, formed through the in situ method, CPM-322 is more porous due to our strategy that the decoupled synthesis permits the use of milder reaction conditions. More importantly, intentional decoupling of the ligand formation process from the MOF crystal growth process provides a new and more flexible route in the kinetic control of MOF synthesis, which may be applied as a general strategy for creating new MOFs, especially homochiral MOFs involving enantiopure ligands (e.g., amino acids) that have the risk of racemization.

cln_elements.content:
With in situ synthesized TPB ligand, CPM-321 was obtained (top) and through pre-synthesized ligand, CPM-322 was obtained (bottom).

Experimental SectionSynthesis of CPM-322 (Zn<sub>2</sub>(<sc>d</sc>-cam)<sub>2</sub>(TPB)<sub>0.5</sub>)

In a 23 mL glass vial, 11.0 mg of d-H2Cam, 11.0 mg of TPB (synthesized according to the literature method), and 34.8 mg of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O were dissolved in 5.0 g of DMF. After being stirred for 30 min, the vial was placed in a 120 °C oven for 4 days, and the mixture was then cooled to room temperature. Pure colorless crystals were obtained (78.0% yield based on metal). The phase purity was supported by powder X-ray diffraction (Figure S1).
cln_elements.clean_text:
a With in situ synthesized TPB ligand, CPM-321 was obtained (top) and through pre-synthesized ligand, CPM-322 was obtained (bottom).  

Experimental Section

Synthesis of CPM-322 (Zn2(d-cam)2(TPB)0.5)

In a 23 mL glass vial, 11.0 mg of d-H2Cam, 11.0 mg of TPB (synthesized according to the literature method), and 34.8 mg of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O were dissolved in 5.0 g of DMF. After being stirred for 30 min, the vial was placed in a 120 °C oven for 4 days, and the mixture was then cooled to room temperature. Pure colorless crystals were obtained (78.0% yield based on metal). The phase purity was supported by powder X-ray diffraction (Figure S1).

cln_elements.content:
A more detailed structural analysis shows that CPM-322 is quite porous, and there is a grid-shaped channel system within the framework. When viewed along the b axis, there is a hexagonal shaped channel through the framework (). This large channel may be potentially useful for inclusion of guest molecules for applications such as gas sorption or chiral separation. A narrower channel can be seen along the a axis (). A calculation by the Platon routine shows that CPM-322 has 51.5% void space, much higher than the void space in CPM-321 (only ∼7.7%).

Thermogravimetric analysis on the as-synthesized sample shows that an initial weight loss of about 25% occurs below 120 °C, which is mainly due to the removal of solvent and other guest molecules (Figure S5). The plateau lasts to about 350 °C with minor weight loss. After that, an obvious weight loss was observed, likely due to the collapse of the structure. In comparison, the weight loss of CPM-321 starts at a lower temperature around 300 °C. The pore properties of CPM-322 were evaluated after successful degassing of the sample (Figure S6). Different methods were used to activate the sample including direct heating and solvent exchange with methanol or dichloromethane. The best result was obtained after solvent exchange with dichloromethane for 3 days followed by further degas at 80 °C. For CPM-322, the CO2 uptake at 1 bar and 273 K reaches 48.8 mg/g.

In comparison, the weight loss of CPM-321 starts at a lower temperature around 300 °C. The pore properties of CPM-322 were evaluated after successful degassing of the sample (Figure S6). Different methods were used to activate the sample including direct heating and solvent exchange with methanol or dichloromethane. The best result was obtained after solvent exchange with dichloromethane for 3 days followed by further degas at 80 °C. For CPM-322, the CO2 uptake at 1 bar and 273 K reaches 48.8 mg/g.

Schematic Illustration on the Synthesis of Two Homochiral Frameworks through Two Different Routes<xref rid="sch1-fn1"></xref>

With in situ synthesized TPB ligand, CPM-321 was obtained (top) and through pre-synthesized ligand, CPM-322 was obtained (bottom).
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic Illustration on the Synthesis of Two Homochiral Frameworks through Two Different Routes      a With in situ synthesized TPB ligand, CPM-321 was obtained (top) and through pre-synthesized ligand, CPM-322 was obtained (bottom).

cln_elements.content: Local structural feature in CPM-322. (a) The occurrence of size and symmetry matching between TPB ligand and two adjacent paddlewheel units makes it possible for multiple connection between the pillar and layer. (b) A comparison between the distorted paddlewheel in CPM-322 (top) and a regular paddlewheel (bottom).

(b) A comparison between the distorted paddlewheel in CPM-322 (top) and a regular paddlewheel (bottom).

Cyan balls represent the Zn dimer and gold balls represent the center of TPB.

metadata.title:
Comparative Study of In Situ and Presynthesized X‑Pillar
Ligand in Self-Assembly of Homochiral Porous Frameworks
